DOC.HEAD: U.S. Blasts Crackdown on Demonstrators
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today accused the government of Romania of ``brutal repression'' in opening fire on anti-government protesters in the capital of Bucharest and in the city of Timisoara. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater also dismissed any suggestions of a parallel between the bloody crackdown and on the U.S. military invasion of Panama on Wednesday. Romania, a hardline Soviet ally, condemned the United States for ``brutal aggression'' in Panama. But Fitzwater insisted that the United States was reinforcing the will of the Panamanian people with its military action. At his daily news briefing, Fitzwater was asked why Panama was different. ``They had an election there that registered the people's wishes'' to be rid of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega ``by a three-to-one margin,'' he replied. Of Romania, Fitzwater said: ``We understand the demonstrations there are continuing. We are monitoring the situation.'' He called on the Romanian government to ``cease its brutal repression of these demostrators, open its borders and respect the Helsinki commitments'' to human rights. ``A state of emergency exists in western Romania,'' Fitzwater said. ``We do maintain there was a bloody massacre'' in the city of Timisoara, where soldiers and police reportedly fired on hundreds and perhaps thousands of people. ``We assume there are considerable numers of people wounded and injured in these demonstrations,'' Fitzwater said.
